comments.text: We've got lots of experience using Coreldraw for our own laser-cut projects. It's a fine tool for designing, albeit not quite as good as a proper 2D CAD package like AutoCAD LT (or anything modern). I used to train operators in AutoCAD (V14 was my last experience, a lifetime ago), and there's some 2D features I sorely miss, but have work-arounds for in Corel X6. It's still a very capable tool for this purpose.

title: 100mm tall round feet for CTC/MakerBot etc

description.text:
I needed some height on my CTC printer, so I took a design for feet and put some height and girth on the model. There is a small cut-out for some sticky-back rubber feet on the bottom to prevent slippage, however, you could just use some sticky-back rubber on the bottom to do the same.

Unfortunately, I can't find the original model to link it off

Edited in Open SCAD.

description.text:
I know, I know, its on the wrong axis....for some reason? ...also IGNORE the three little rectangles waaaay off to the right of the actual rack.
Let me know if you make it, I'd be really interested
Working with a company I was asked to design a storage rack to hold at least 45 2.5" SSDs. These SSDs contained vital emergency backup images of the machines on the production floor.
I designed a total of 26 drawers which can hold 2 SSDs per drawer.

Total Capacity of Storage Rack is 52 SSDs. Specifically, Intel 530 Series 480GB SSDs.
It's approx. (26cm x 18cm x 18cm) (L x W x H) not including the handle on top.
The locking mechanism on the front locks all the SSD trays in place using a multiple bolting system. The key when turned would allow all SSDs to be unlocked at the same time. The lock design is very basic and I'm not sure if it would be usable or ideal so it's up to you whether or not you want to use that or some other method.

The doors at the front are clear acrylic plastic(plexiiglass) with a metal frame that can be locked with a padlock

This is supposed to be made of metal but I said I'd share it incase you guys wanted to tweak the shit out of it.

I haven't made it so it could go very wrong if you try to(especially the locking mechanism which is enclosed behind the front panel with the "lock" on it.

Ring Size: 8.5

Ring Diameter : 18.7

title: Modified X-ends for the Aluminatus - V2

description.text:
Note: These X-ends are designed to match the lead screw nuts having triangular flanges.   
These are slightly taller allowing the bearings to be spread a bit. They are designed to sit on top of the lead screw nut with the nut passing thru the flange. Small rubber washers are installed between the lead screw nut's flange and the flange of the x-end. Because it is taller, screws and t-nuts can be placed in all three slots of the extrusion it mounts onto. The two outboard holes will mount to the extrusion as well, if it is long enough.  
This design is derived from the original designs of the Aluminatus.   
The photo is of version 1.

None - print it as you would any structural part.  
It can be printed without supports, but there may be some minor trouble with bridging the tops of the nut-traps.

a Vigenère (polyalphabetic) code wheel used to simplify the
Vigenère code.
this uses an alphabet composed of 16 characters.

to use the wheel, you must first:
A) make a 16 letter alphabet. for exemple, 1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9,abcdefg
B) mark each 1/16 of the wheel with a coresponding letter.
C) make a keyword out of the alphabet you created. for exemple: 1567
D) the wheel is just a simplifacation of the Vigenère chart.
in this alphabet, the Vigenère chart will look like this:
123456789abcdefg
23456789abcdefg1
3456789abcdefg12
456789abcdefg123
56789abcdefg1234
6789abcdefg12345
789abcdefg123456
89abcdefg1234567
9abcdefg12345678
abcdefg123456789
bcdefg123456789a
cdefg123456789ab
defg123456789abc
efg123456789abcd
fg123456789abcde
g123456789abcdef
123456789abcdeg
so, if your keyword is 1567, and the text you wnat to encrypt is
a351, then you write the keyword above the text 1567 like this,
a351
and now you can encrypt it.
E) after we wrote the key above the text, we go to the Vigenère chart and look at the alphabet that starts with the coresponding letter we want to encrypt, using the key (for exemple, the alphabet that we will use to encrypt the letter "a" will start with one).
now, we look at the place the letter we want to encrypt is in in the normal alphabet (in our alphabet, the letter "a" is in the10th spot).
the letter a=10, so we go to the alphabet that starts with 1,
and there look at the 10th spot.
result? a=a.
so 1567
a351
a
using this process, we can fill out the rest of the message. 

1567  
a351  
a7a7

so using the code, a351=a7a7.
F) how does the wheel help with all this?
figure out yourself.
it is very tiring to write out guides like this.

comments.author: Skeaffaber

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/5MnTHrzKOLP

If you have a regular NEMA17 or NEMA23 motor that you are not using you can create a GREAT horizontal filament spool base. The motor adds weight and stability to the spool, besides and most important, its RESISTANCE to rotation!! This way your spool never will be unwinded by a filament whiplash (specially the large brand new ones, that tends to unwind itselves) Just add some M4 and M3 screws, some M3 nuts and you are done. You just slide off the adapter to be able to insert little hole spool or make easily your own adapter editing the FreeCAD sources included. About the colors used to print, errr... Just printed with what was loaded on my printers at that time... There are two variants, the conical regular one, and what I call the 'cube mod' that is a modular design easier to print but it requires 4 more screws and nuts. I use both of them, but I printed more the cube mod because being modular it can take advantage of that surplus filament you can have around. Regular STLS are for NEMA23 Version. If you want a NEMA17 version just print instead the two NEMA17 named stl's. Anyway I recommend to use the NEMA23 version, it adds weight and requires more torque thus increasing performance. Of course the NEMA17 version is also a good performer. Just use what you have around.

I use this kind of supports to feed filament to my printers through a PTFE tube directly to the extruder, this avoids the spool weight pending on the machine, increasing stability and giving you more freedom to manipulate/place your spools in addition of filament bending protection. If you use 1.75mm filament just get couple meters of 3mm inner PTFE tube and try it. I promise you'll never regret... The optional toolbox is also very handy, it even has an optional hinged top.

TODO: Nothing. Original project goal surpassed.

Happy unwinding!!

Updates:

UPDATE (18-FEB-2016): Just added a POV rendering.

UPDATE (10-SEP-2015): Enhanced hinge.

UPDATE (9-SEP-2015): Added: shell to 38mm, shell to 50mm from 38mm. Increased the 14mm axis base to 30mm diameter for better fitting after filing the support material from the spool base. Added a toolbox top and a hinge to install it. Use M3 screws and wood screws to install the hinge, and a M3 30mm screw and a M3 nutlock for the hinge.

UPDATE (7-SEP-2015): Added convenient NEMA17 STL's for the cube mod, the coil base and the cube mod top. The spool adapters remains compatible with both NEMA23 and NEMA17 versions. The NEMA17 version requires four M3 screws instead of four M4 screws. Amplified the base coil diameter to 140mm. There is no NEMA17 'cone version' at this moment. Added also STL's for an optional (or several) side tool boxes. Use the Cube mod stl with holes for each toolbox.

UPDATE (5-SEP-2015): Introducing the 'Cube Mod' easier to print specially on ABS. A total of 8 M4 and 3 M3 nuts & bolts required. Updated STL's for a better fitting of nuts. Added an adapter to 50mm spools on top of the 30mm adapter, You choose what to use depending on your needs.

UPDATE (4-SEP-2015): Added pics, updated tolerances for shells to avoid filing and updated STL's according.

UPDATE (3-SEP-2015): Rectified nut holes to avoid filing. Added a shell for 50mm hole spools.

UPDATE (2-SEP-2015): Added a hollow to shelter the motor axis in the 14mm adapter, This allow to install the motor without trimming its axis. Updated STL's. Remember to add support to the spool base.

A portable gaming system built using a Raspberry Pi and touchscreen display for the Raspberry Pi with Java book.

Kid tested and approved!

The NightHacking RetroPi is designed to be straightforward to print (no generated supports required), straightforward to source (almost everything can be ordered from one supplier), and simple to assemble (snap together design).

I do go into more detail in my book, but want this to be a project anyone can print, so I have included all the source files, instructions, and detailed pictures here. If there is something I missed, please let me know and I will include it.

Here is what you need to finish the project:

  • Raspberry Pi 2 - https://www.adafruit.com/products/2358
  • SD Card with NOOBS - https://www.adafruit.com/products/1583
  • Adafruit DPI TFT Kippah for Raspberry Pi with Touch Support - https://www.adafruit.com/products/2453
  • 40-pin FPC Extension Board + 200mm Cable - https://www.adafruit.com/products/2098
  • 4.3" 40-pin TFT Display - 480x272 with Touchscreen - https://www.adafruit.com/products/1591
  • Mini Metal Speaker w/ Wires - 8 ohm 0.5W - https://www.adafruit.com/products/1890
  • Stereo 2.8W Class D Audio Amplifier - TS2012 - https://www.adafruit.com/products/1552
  • Thru-hole 5-way Navigation switch (Alps Model SKQUCAA010) - https://www.adafruit.com/products/504
  • Tactile Switch Buttons (12mm square, 6mm tall) x 10 pack - https://www.adafruit.com/products/1119
  • 2x C&K D6F90 F1 LFS Switch – http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/D6F90%20F1%20LFS/401-1970-ND/1466327
  • 1N4148 Diodes - https://www.adafruit.com/products/1641
  • PowerBoost 1000 Charger - Rechargeable 5V Lipo USB Boost @ 1A – https://www.adafruit.com/products/2465
  • Lithium Ion Battery Pack - 3.7V 4400mAh - https://www.adafruit.com/products/354
  • Breadboard-friendly SPDT Slide Switch - https://www.adafruit.com/products/805

For printing, I recommend 100 micron layer height (or finer) and thick walls (>= 1mm). Most parts can be printed with minimal infill, except the pins, which I recommend doing at 80% infill or greater. All the parts are oriented in the correct position in the exported STL files except for the pins (which should be printed with the nuts facing the build platform.

To assemble the RetroPi, here is the basic list of steps (with the corresponding pictures roughly in order):

  • Print all the parts for the project and check against the photo to make sure you have everything ready.
  • Solder a couple cables to the Raspberry Pi audio pads shown in the diagram (PP6 is ground and PP26 is the right channel). In general, a cable length of 10-12mm is about right for this and all the future connections.
  • Put the Raspberry Pi and Battery into the base (both of which have form fit holes)
  • Solder the Kippah 5V and Ground lines to the matching PowerBoost 1000C terminals. Also, connect the slide switch to the EN and GND pins on the PowerBoost (you only need to connect 2 of the 3 switch terminals).
  • Insert the PowerBoost and switch into the case per the photo.
  • Solder cables from the Kippah to all the buttons. Refer to the chart below for the wiring of buttons.
  • Attach the 200mm ribbon cable to the Kippah and gently tuck it under (no hard creases).
  • Attach the Kippah to the Raspberry Pi GPIO pins, being careful to route the cables and make sure the Kippah can lay perfectly flat.
  • Insert the D-Pad holder and add the 5-way switch to the form-fit slot. You can also pop the D-Pad printed part on at this time.
  • Insert the Button holder into the form-fit slot, and insert the 4 buttons into their respective holes. Pay attention to the direction of the A and B buttons, which only fit in one orientation with both flat edges facing each other.
  • Attach the screen base and carefully route the ribbon cable through the hinge by rolling it gently (again, be careful not to sharply bend or crease the ribbon cable).
  • Insert the left and right pins with the lock cutout facing up. They will fit best when the screen is open at a 120 degree angle. Then secure by adding the locks from the top (if they are tight, squeeze them into place with pliers).
  • Add the extension board and touch screen to the top. It is a tight fit, so be careful not to pinch the screen cable when inserting it.
  • Attach the console lid and screen lids. They are designed to slide and snap into place securely with no screws.

Here are the button assignments:

Kippah Lead Connection 1 Connection 2 Connection 3
Ground 2 Navigation – Select button – Start button –
Ground 3 B button – A button –
GPIO 27 B button +
GPIO 22 A button +
GPIO 23 Navigation left Select diode 1
GPIO 24 Navigation down Start diode 1
GPIO 25 Navigation right Select diode 2
GPIO 26 Navigation up Start diode 2

To run games, I have a modified version of the Java HalfNes emulator with GPIO controller support. You can find that codebase here:
https://github.com/RaspberryPiWithJava/halfnes

The Raspberry Pi comes with Java preinstalled, so you just need to load this project up in NetBeans and do a remote deployment. The main class is com.grapeshot.halfnes.JavaFXNES.

I also recommend the following "tweaks" to your /boot/config.txt:

Disable spi and i2c, we need these pins.

dtparam=spi=off  
dtparam=i2c_arm=off  
# enable the DPI display  
enable_dpi_lcd=1  
display_default_lcd=1  
# For 4.3in displays  
hdmi_ignore_edid=0xa5000080  
hdmi_ignore_edid_audio=1  
# Use these instead if you need to work on console:  
# framebuffer_width=480  
# framebuffer_height=272  
# These work with JavaFX:  
framebuffer_width=640  
framebuffer_height=472  
dpi_output_format=520197  
# Flip the screen  
display_rotate=2  
# And adjust overscan as necessary  
disable_overscan=0  
overscan_top=150  
overscan_left=160  
overscan_right=0  
overscan_bottom=-59  
# Increase GPU memory:  
gpu_mem=128

I also recommend a little overclocking. I did some burn-in testing, and these values seem to be pretty reliable on my Raspberry Pi 2 (your mileage may vary):

overclocking

arm_freq=1050  
over_voltage=4  
core_freq=525  
gpu_freq=350  
sdram_freq=480  
over_voltage_sdram=2

Regardless of whether you overclock or not, you will need to change the governor on the Raspberry Pi 2 to be more aggressive so it will perform better. The default governor sees that only 1 CPU is busy and will throttle you to 600MHz, which is no good:
echo "performance" | sudo tee /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_governor

Good luck with printing and assembling your RetroPi, and please let me know how your project goes by commenting on the project here and posting pictures of your creation!

This is a great idea. Would you be able to make edits to accommodate 4 buttons, as well as L & R triggers?
This way, you can play more then just NES games.
comments.author: slade4g63

comments.text: XY buttons would be easy to add, and it is possible to modify the design to include L/R triggers (although you would have to make the case slightly bigger on the back).  However, the reason I did not include these is due to the GPIO limitation on the Kippah.  With only six GPIO available, wiring up the additional 4 buttons will be challenging.  A standard row/column matrix with 3 pins will only give you 9 inputs (only 1 more than what I describe in the wiring section of this implementation).  However, using charlieplexing you should be able to get 6x5 (30) discrete inputs, which is more than enough.  You will need a lot more diodes and a rat's nest of wiring to get it working, though.  :)  [and of course you could always wire a microcontroller in and bit-bang serial or another communication protocol...  that saves you on wiring, but adds complexity in other ways]

Enclosure for the small stereo amp kit sold by Sparkfun (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9612). This enclosure also includes space and cutouts for an external power switch, RCA audio-in jacks, a power jack and a 4 spring speaker terminal.

Case lid screws to base using 4 M3 x 12 mm socket head screws. The board screws into the bottom of the case using the provided screws in the amplifier kit. The RCA and power jacks are mounted upside down to the inbuilt shelf to provide easier access to the pins since the platform is not removable. I added a version with break away tree-like support structures generated by the slicer of my FlashForge Finder from Gearbest (Affiliate link: https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printers-3d-printer-kits/pp_693032.html?lkid=11324000). You can generate it automatically with FlashPrint and edit the structures too.

I used VisCAM to edit and combine the parts and MeshMixer to edit and sculpt the model with different brushes. I made a plane cut on the bottom (feet) for stability while/after printing.

description.text:
Hey if you want an LED light that you can simply point to the area of interest on the print bed, then use this simple hack. We find that a flexible lamp let's us put the light where it's needed.

This is based on the Improved Parametric Extrusion End Cap (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:992119) so this hack should work for any other aluminum extrusion based CNC or 3D Printer with an exposed upright.

After printing the replacement end cap, you're going to take apart the the clamp style lamp and do a little rewiring:

  • First
    Print a new end cap for the top of double wide extrusion (this can be found http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:992119. The default OpenSCAD settings and Double Wide with One Hole stl files are ready to go for the end cap. You may have to repair the object with netfabb - still debugging why it's not manifold. Otherwise use the attached fixed stl file.

  • Second
    Get the JANSJÖ lamp at IKEA (I think it cost something around 10 EUR or 15 USD). We got the model with the clamp -I'm not sure if the desktop model can be disassembled. If someone finds out please let me know and we'll update this post.

  • Third
    Take apart the lamp and discard the clamping base. Wire the lamp through the hole in the extrusion to get to the extrusion center shaft. Screw the lamp through the new end cap and into the the threaded center shaft (if you got a Felix Printer). Everyone else, tap threads into the center shaft as necessary.

By the way the precut treads on the Felix are different than the lamps but the lamp will catch - just don't destroy the the extrusion threading by over tightening.

When finished it should look like the gallery photos.

Its simple printed fillament spool. Sizes are 31mm hole, 320mm outer diameter 200mm inner diameter, 150mm wide. It can teoreticaly hold up to 7 dm3 material.
U need 6 outer parts and one central ring. I prefer to print it from ABS-T and then gloue it together with acetone juice. Parts just fit to my 210*230 mm table

I tried to print Arnitel. This was too flexible that the original design can transport the filament, because the gap between the top and the base of the extruder was too high. So I decided to make a new extruder. It is near the design of Camiel. I added a one fix point for the idler holder.

You can use all screws from the original extruder. In addition you need a threaded bar 4mm with a length of even 70mm.
After the print sand the shaft a little that it fits into the hole of the extruder top. Slide it in and fasten the threaded bar with a nut in front and in the back. Put a m4 nut into the knob and glue the knob top on it. I use uhu allplast for it. Take a look at the hight of the hot end brass top. The Extruder base is designed for a hight of 19mm. Maybe you need to drill it a little to meet your needs. For the idler holder you need a 25mm screw for the extruder base.

title: Aerial Vista Security Camera w/Motion for Raspberry Pi

description.text:
Update: Check out detailed instructions at
http://www.instructables.com/id/3d-Printed-Raspberry-Pi-Security-Camera/

This is a camera shell for a Raspberry Pi camera. With the Motion program it is a quick and easy installation. This first model is not set for IR lights but I will make a second version that does so that you can use either pi camera.

Here is a link to a tutorial by user (GUS) on how to set up Motion on your Raspberry Pi.

http://pimylifeup.com/raspberry-pi-security-camera/

Update: The wall mount files have been added

http://www.instructables.com/id/3d-Printed-Raspberry-Pi-Security-Camera/ go here for instructions and to vote on my instructable

I printed with PETG but it can be printed with most anything. Some parts need support to print. I also use a brim. The support is minimal.

This is a work in progress so I need to finish placing the countersunk screw holes in the mounting base.

I realized that I have drawn this for the sainsmart NOIR camera so I will add a version 2 that is for the official Picam.

I used m3 8mmstainless button heads all around except two black socket caps for the rpi because they are cheaper and a stainless socket cap m3 20mm on the base. The camera housing to base connection is an M4 20mm.

description.text:
A custom designed mount which allows you to attach your Knog Blinder to the back of a Topeak bike rack (May fit other racks as well?)
You can use the two extra screws that come with the Topeak rack to fix the custom mount in place, and then simply strap the Blinder in place. You will need two additional nuts though!

The mount can be mounted as shown in the picture OR fipped to the INSIDE of the bike rack, which makes the Knog Blinder only stick out a few millimeters out of the back.
Make sure to print this part so the mounting plate is facing the build platform for extra strength.

This is a 1 to 1 scale Police Blaster from the movie The Fifth Element. I created this in Tinkercad and did my best to capture all the detail I could from photo reference of a screen used prop. It isn't perfect but it is pretty damn close to the actual prop.

Please Note: I left room inside for electronics. The main tube is hollow allowing room for a battery pack, LED's and an LCD readout. The handle has space to allow for an LED and/or more batteries. The trigger is static as well as the side knobs. The knob on the right side is designed to be able to slide along the slot. You may want to add a spring for resistance.
Basically print everything out and assemble.

title: Minecraft structure planner to OpenSCAD Ruby converter

description.text:
I've been working on this Ruby script on and off for a while now, but never felt it was ready for distribution. Then http://minecraftprint.com/ came along, and made me push an early version out. While I see the benefit of being able to search through an entire world and pick out the structure to print, it's not really an option for larger worlds, and the selection method seemed cumbersome. My idea is to use an established file format as the base for conversion - http://www.minecraftwiki.net/wiki/Schematic_File_Format The worldwide Minecraft communities create and read this format with an assortments of tools. At the server I play on, we use World Edit, with it you can select and save areas of the world to file very easy. To make it simpler to convert I send the schematic file through Minecraft structure planner which exports to xml. At the moment the script is VERY crude. It runs through a Minecraft Structure Planner xml file and creates a OpenSCAD file where it places a cube(); (and it's block type) every time it finds a block. Warning: This is the first time I've touched Ruby, so if you know how to use it, my sincere apologies in advance. I hope someone else might want to build upon this work/idea. :-) Planned improvements:
Converting slabs, stairs, fences and perhaps other objects.
Using a special block for support structure.
Output optimization so it's possible to convert large structures. Future improvements:
Reading the World Edit schematic files directly.
Exporting to stl directly with World Edit?

In short:
Use world edit to save schematic, convert it to xml with minecraft structure planner, run mc.rb and use OpenScad to convert the file to stl. In long:
You need Ruby - http://www.ruby-lang.org/ and the xmlsimple gem - http://xml-simple.rubyforge.org/
Minecraft Structure Planner (MSP) - http://minecraftstructureplanner.com/ I have only tried to convert others schematics, and simple ones I've made myself in MSP. But here's some pointers to how you could go along: To copy buildings from a server it needs to run Bukkit - http://www.bukkit.org - with World Edit - http://www.minecraftforum.net/topic/42214-pluginbukkit-worldedit-32-feature-rich-13-01/
For single player you can use single player commands and World Edit - http://www.minecraftforum.net/topic/94310-173-single-player-commands-v210-2-another-new-update/ Select the area you want to copy/print. ( I like to use //wand )
Use //save filename
Somehow fish out the .schematic file from the server folder.
Import the schematic file into MSP and save it in the MSP xml format, in the same folder as mc.rb.
Rename the file test.xsp (or edit mc.rb and change the file name)
Run mc.rb
Open test.scad and enjoy your work. Notes/limitations:
There's a hard limit on (I guess) the number of objects possible in OpenSCAD, and since it converts every single block as a cube(); it reaches that limit pretty fast. So this version only works with small buildings. There need to be at least one block in every column, as there's no check for empty columns at the moment. The easiest way to fix this is to lay a full base on the first layer. OpenSCAD takes forever to render the file. The object might come out mirrored, as I can't quite recall which version I fixed that in. :-P

title: Lipo upgrade for Tamiya Lunchbox & Midnight Pumpkin

description.text:
The Tamiya Lunchbox 1/12 scale RC Monster Truck was designed around a classic NiCd/NiMH battery pack. Modern hard case LiPo packs have a hard time fitting the model due to the low profile battery slot.  
This modification, consisting out of a slightly longer battery guard as well as 3 spacers to add additional room to the battery compartment, can be printed and installed in minutes.

Print all parts in ABS with 1 additional shell and 100 infill.
It is a good idea to also increase the filament diameter by 0.03 -> 0.04 for a leaner print. The battery guard needs to be printed with raft and external supports. Install the new battery guard in place of the original brace (reuse the 2 original screws) and place the spacer between the out shell and the vehicle body as shown in the picture above. Insert your LiPo Pack and have fun !!!!

comments.text: Yes the Midnight Pumpkin and the Tamiya Lunchbox use the same style frame so it should fit. Hope this helps.

A design Iv been working on for a while that is still in the making. 20x20Y20Z cm build volume. I am redesigning it to be made from plasma cut steel so it can be smaller and use corexy. the sides are meant to fold in to the back. Then the top to the back and then all of it to the bottom. Iv designed it to have the motors and electronics in the bottom to help it from being top heavy. Ill be using fishing line routed to the top similar to sublimes design. The bed will be designed to be removable and will be held on top the assembly when collapsed. the hot end will be made to be quickly removed by loosening a jam nut on the Bowden Coupling and a slot to remove without disconnecting the tube. All of the components are designed to be made using a 5mm end mill. the motors I am using are the 56oz-in 14HS20. Influenced by the FoldaRap the Tantillus and the Ditto.

Install Python or TCL. I think for Mac the python version is better.
For python You also need http://pyserial.sourceforge.net
Edit the script and change the Device and Baudrate.
Then call it like: ./feeder.py Your-Nice-File.gcode

title: Hinges for Acrylic Doors for Makerbot Replcator 2 / 2X, Flashforge Creator Metal, and similar style 3D printers

description.text:
These hinges are for 3mm Acrylic Doors (ex: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:991861) to flush fit on the Makerbot Replicator 2 / 2X and similar clones with the metal frames and 5mm plastic side panels. These hinges attach to the Acrylic doors with 10mm Flathead M3 machine screws, and attach to the plastic panels with 12mm M3 machine screws. You should also use the stress relieving printed plastic hex washers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755320) when attaching these hinges. These hinges, along with the associate latch are part of an enclosure kit which includes the snap together (as in no fasteners top) for these style printers. The enclosure improves printing by maintaining a more consistent print environment, reducing warping and delamination.

The kit is available at: http://drazzticaction.com/products-page-2/3dprinters/enclosure-for-makerbot-replicator-2-2x-3d-printers-and-similar-clones/

Enjoy better prints

title: Wall mount for the Ikea JANSJÖ desk led lamp

description.text:
I have a very nice Ikea LED desk lamp you can find here:
http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/20169658/
Because I have very limited desk space I've decided to build a wall mount for it. You can easily dismount the lamp base using a screwdriver.
The mount contains only 2 pieces. One to be fixed on the wall with 2 screws and one where the lamp is fixed using own screws from the base.
In the lower part of the main module a simple power switch is mounted and a 3mm standard red LED connected through a 390ohm resistor in parallel with the lamp (take care at the polarity).
The LED lights up only when the lamp is off. This helps locating the lamp switch in the dark.
Just print the 2 parts in your prefered material and fix the small one on the wall. The main part just slides over the piece mounted on the wall. No need for glue or other screws.

author: tdanro

description.text:
I love my Glue Pen. It supercharges my printing bed and everything sticks af. But when you just lay it on its side, the little bastard begins to drop a little bit and the cap fills with glue.

So, this little thing was created. It fits perfect under the dampening material of my k8200.

A heated build chamber which uses an oven/turkey bag. This has the advantage of being easy and cheap to make as well as not weakening all the plastic parts in your RepRap, unlike fully enclosing your machine.

There's not really much to this. Just get a cheap oven roasting bag of the right size and cut it so that it forms a single sheet. Then print out the guard/retained and attach to an appropriate point on your extruder. If you use an extruder other than a Budaschnozzle, simply modify the parametric openSCAD file. Note that it will give a design with a circular hole. Then all you have to do is hold the bag down on the corners of your bed using bulldog clips then tape or use rubber bands to fix the other end of the bag to the guard. I found this technique to be pretty effective, zero warp in the part that I printed, though it wasn't a particularly hard print anyway. At a guess, I would say that the temperature within the bag is at least 50 or 60 degrees C. A few things to note:
This has to be printed in ABS due to how close it is to the extruder.
Make sure you don't block off any heatsinks or dissipation devices on your extruder. Thermal barriers, such as the PEEK parts should be OK as they don't really have to do any dissipating. At least my extruder was working fine.
This design is nowhere near perfect. For one, the guard should be made a bit shorter to provide more clearance from stuff on the bed like bulldog clips. Also, the bag tends to slip on the guard so a rim or something could be added.
Watch out for the guard warping under heat as well. Though mine didn't have any catastrophic softening, the edge of the guard shrunk a bit from the constant force of a rubber band holding the bag on it.

This is an all-metal design for a RepRap frame that I came up with while on vacation in Puerto Rico.  Resources on the island are very limited, but I did find the local Home Depot around the corner, and there was a stash of tools, including a drill and hack saw, in one of the closets of the apartment we rented.
Jibaro is a word that refers to some of the island's rural inhabitants.  They tend to grow their own food, and raise chickens and hogs.  They are very resourceful, and creative.  Many of the craftsmen might be considered jibaros.

Note:  There is a new "compatible" vertex which uses a shorter length of bar.  It's closer to the size of the regular Mendel vertex.
I did not have time to complete the frame while on the island, but I do intend on continuing this design, at least for now.
To construct the vertex part (you will need 6 of these), begin by using a hack saw to cut a 5.25" length of punched bar.  The ends of the bar should begin at the center of a hole.  If this is not the case, make it so, otherwise the holes will not be in the right positions.
In this piece, you are then going to saw six (6) slots into the metal, about half way through.  These will become your bend points.
From the outside in, the distances are 0.375", 0.75", and 1.875" on both ends.
The four bends closest to the ends are 90 degrees, and the two (2) innermost bends, are 150 degrees.  This is consistent with the regular RepRap Mendel-type machines.
Use pliers to bend at the marks.  Once you have three of these vetexes bent, you can place them end to end to check the 150 degree angles.  They should be flush against each other.  Adjust if necessary.

Just a quick proof of concept for a modular set up (will upload more decorative and unique versions). Easy to print and assemble. The pins are used to hold the strings/rubbrbands, they lock into place in the square notches.   You can actually just use one rubberband and weave it throughout.  
EDIT: Fixeded the model for the pins, they weren't fitting well, now they're perfect. Modeling a bridge to help raise the "strings" because they are too close to the body, doesn't allow for a good sound. Should be uploaded by the time you read this.  
Have fun! I'll print this soon and post pics!

• Print the body. I used 5% infill no support or raft. 2 shells.

  • Print 10 pins. 15% infill 3 shells no support.

  • Print a bridge (you'll need to glue this on. I'll design a new vs soon with notches though.

  • Put the pins into place on the body. Do so by insert them by the rectangular end. Then turn each piece so the flat bottom part of the circular end points towards the center of the body.

  • Weave a rubberband, string, or whatever you like through the pins.

  • Place the bridge wherever you want in order to raise the strings. Glue it if tension alone is not enough.

  • Play a sweet riff and get all the glory. Or play the song of your people and summon an ancient war beast. Play us a melody and sing the tale of our journeys... or you know...just kinda leave it on a shelf as a conversation piece...which is more likely... Rock on!

An alternate way to charge your motorola xoom via the docking tabs.

I broke my original charging connector. Rather than spend $$$ on a replacement I made this simple connector that uses the dock connection instead. 2 header pins, a couple of magnets and some super glue. This is my first draft. It works but I plan on some improvements like strain relief.
The motorola xoom needs 12v to charge. +12v is the tab closest to the power connector (RHS when looking at the screen)

A brushless motor mount designed to accommodate 10mm stand-off motor mounts - http://www.hobbyking.co.uk/hobbyking/store/__9869__Electric_Motor_StandOff_Mounts_10mm_Small_base_5pcs_bag_.html

The mount was originally designed for, and works perfectly fitted to a scratch-built foam flying wing of a 10mm (2 sheets of depron) thickness at the point of attachment.

M3 nuts and bolts are utilised for securing to the aircraft.

A SLDPRT file is provided to allow for adjustments to accommodate varying stand-off sizes, foam thickness and bolt sizes.

Layer Height - 0.2mm
Infill - 25 - 50%
No supports required depending on print orientation.

author: antoonjan

title: Quick change bearing based spool holder

description.text:
I was frustrated with having to use a hex wrench to remove my spools from the bearing based holder I was using. This one uses super magnets to join the two sides, and springs to keep tension on the spool. It's pretty simple, and self guides as you push the two sides together. It's fully functional as it is now.

Here is a video of it in action: https://youtu.be/HKhCh__cVko

Updates:
I added a shorter shaft to take advantage of the shorter spring in the 4 pack from Home Depot.(Main-short.stl)

I added a spot to press in the nut, and recess the M3 screw into the tensioners. Otherwise the bolt wouldn't be long enough.

I added a press in cover to be installed after the bearing is pressed in. I found that once the PLA gets too warm the bearing can loosen, This seems to keep everything together. I'll see if I can put up an assembly diagram tomorrow.

I uploaded an experimental wall mount that I'm in the process of printing now based on feedback from FMA. Preliminary testing suggests that the shorter arm can hold the spool by itself. I'll test it out tomorrow night and report back.

The experimental spindle holder seems to work OK. If you decide to print it out let me know any issue you have. (I'll be making a version for the M2 soon)

Update the links to the springs.

Printing:
I printed the Main2.stl at 60% infill. I had a problem with the springs causing the plastic to de-laminate otherwise. Everything else I printed at 20% infill.

Experimental option: Substitute the spindle arm experimental for on of the main2 arms for wall mount.

Assembly:

  1. The bearings are pressed into the spool holder sides.
  2. The magnets will need to be glued and pressed into the tops of the holders (I used channel locks). Make sure that they are aligned to attract each other and not repulse.
  3. Slide the springs over the arms.
  4. Slide the spool holder on
  5. Then use the m3 nut and screw to attach the magnetic tip.

Parts List:
2 - M3 X 15 mm Screws
2 - M3 nuts
2 - 608zz 8x22x7 bearings
2 - 1/2" X 1-1/2" X .041" inch springs
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-1-2-in-x-1-1-2-in-and-7-16-in-x-2-1-8-in-Zinc-Plated-Compression-Springs-4-Pack-16072/202045476?keyword=1%2F2%22x1-1%2F2%22+compression
2 - 1/2" (12mm) super magnets
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Master-Magnetics-1-2-in-Neodymium-Rare-Earth-Magnet-Discs-6-per-Pack-07046HD/202526367?keyword=1%2F2+inch+super+magnet

I had a comment from a Jasper1984 that the ball joints he printed were not holding in position well (on my earlier model an so I thought of making a socket that can have adjustable tension by using rubber bands.
my earlier model :http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:86194
was intended for a smaller scale.
this model is bigger and should be easier to mount.
the socket has indentation on the outside to hold a rubber band in place.
I found using a band tightened the hold quite a bit and a stronger band would make it tighter still. (note only put the band on once the
ball is in the socket, otherwise the socket could get damaged).
I made the shaft have a increased surface area to make it stronger, and added a second hole to make attachment more secure.

my prints
10 % infill
2 shells
ABS
.27 slice.

comments.text:
I would not think these would be the best choice.
that said, I would make a larger print (scale the model up( both are together so they should remain proportional))
once you have a larger print you can do some tests without committing to a whole skeleton model.
as to search, there is a search on thingiverse which sucks but does work.
finally sometimes mixed media is a better choice. the bones printed, but the joint can be a add on (metal/wood/ etc)

*** Tank Silicone Repair **

Cut the edges of the silicone mat
and she pull from the edge
Take sylgard 184 by Dow Corning
Mixing ratio 1:10 Silicone /Hardener
Stir for 5 minutes be sure to mix all the materials from the walls and bottom of the cup
just leave it sit for 30min
In the tank casting
Set this aside and leave cure overnight. 
If you want to cure it quicker place it in the oven at 80 deg C for about an hour. 

YOU HAVE A NEW SILICONE TANK :)

description.text:
Gross out your friends with this awesome stink bomb that can be made from materials around the house! Using rotten garlic and sulfur technology, this is one of the most advanced and gross stink bombs available. If you don't have a 3D printer, we have created a stink grenade kit which can be purchased from the link below. We've created a complete through tutorial on how to build your stink bomb here: http://youtu.be/Vu8RfzIAMtY

Make sure to check out our other videos at BANANA SCIENCE: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKl9Rvfkb5HyUC7cnUbBZ5g

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Use your default settings

Infill:

1-20%

Notes:

Body casing: Print in ABS or PLA with supports. There is no need for a raft. If you happen to be using simplify 3D as a slicer or any other slicing program that supports custom supports, only add supports on the very bottom, not inside the casing.

Spoon: Print with a raft and supports in ABS or PLA.

author: antoonjan

description.text:
I have been building a RigidBot Big I bought via eBay. The previous owner had not taken care of it and there was broken parts etc.

Here I have designed a new X carriage for a bowden setup with a Pico hotend.

As a note about building on this printer I even added code to the Marlin firmware just to be able to compensate the warped build plate.
https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/pull/1619
https://github.com/epatel/Marlin/blob/75f9fb50c4002f6d4ba0345f5594cbac1fab1fa6/Documentation/MeshBedLeveling.md

author: denis0k

title: Dominion ExoKnights (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Well, the Wayfarer Tactics Kickstarter campaign is moving right along tanks to our amazing backers! We're still in the early stretch, and a lot more rewards will be added, so be sure and check in and drop us a pledge! Here are some 18mm scale (Pocket-Tactics sized) versions of the Dominion ExoKnights, models that are featured in our B-tier rewards (28mm scale) and that will feature into the eventual rules codex. They're a powerful division of the Trans-Universal Dominion that are able to act with autonomy, forgoing the usual labyrinthine protocol to act in the best interest of the worlds under their protection.

Wayfarer Tactics is a dynamic miniature wargaming system. With these rules, you can use models from your collection to enact skirmishes, large-scale battles, or party-centered dungeon crawls. Based loosely on our Wayfarer multiverse setting, you can stage your battles in worlds of magic-rich high fantasy, far-flung intergalactic scifi, or anything in between.

Check out our Kickstarter Video!

In addition, we've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Wayfarer Tactics. Check it out here.

Enjoy!
Printed at a .1 layer height with 15% infill. Printed in halves and assembled with model glue.

author: hkmagno

description.text:
Stylised Mammoth head to be used as a multi-purpose hook i.e. coat hook, towels, utensils etc.

Can either be attached to a wall with screws or hung over a door frame using the additional bracket.

Mammoth dimensions:

107mm x 63mm approx

Due to the semi complex geometry of the mammoth head this was modelled outside of 123D Design, however the bracket was.

Model can be scaled however you will also need to adjust the bracket dimensions to match.

The door bracket is currently scaled to fit a 37mm thick door. The bracket should slide into the back of the mammoth head.

In addition the mammoth head can be screwed into a wall, thus no need for the additional bracket
This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/p/acc0c4c87b241dbc
Just a small little mouse-shaped toy for cats. The hole in the back is for yarn so you can give it a fluffy tail~!

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Z-Axis Endstop Switch Bracket

description.text:
This is a mod I made to the one designed by evadeninja (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:906366) I made the Slots wider

Both Brackets have 2x 2.5mm Holes for Switch mounting w/ 4mm Hex for m2 Hex Nuts on back side. and Permits Flush Mounting to frame. Also 2.5mm wide Slots for Height Adjustable Mounting in Factpry Threaded Holes in support arm.

Versions are marked on Top for Reference
v1: Slots are .3 mm from Nuts total of 14.5 mm Travel
..... Works Great for the 3/32 glass I bought from Lowe's.
..... Can raise bed almost all the way up and NOT hit the extruder when HOMED

v2: Slots are 1.8mm from Nuts total of 13.0 mm Travel
..... works for thicker Glass

Created this part in Autodesk Inventor 2012
Printed Using Cura with Makergeeks 'Dark as Night PLA'
...I had to scale it x10 to get it proper size 1 : 1

My Cura Setting:
Layer Height: .3
Shell Thickness: .8
Bottom/ Top Thickness: .6

Print Speed: 50 mm/s
Printing Temp: 230 C
Bed Temp: 50 C

Support Type: None

MY INSTALLATION:
Remove Existing 2m screws that hold Switch
... be careful of the 2 nylon spacers
Install 2 Nuts on m2 x 12mm screws all the way up to head
Place 2 m2 nuts into hex on back of bracket
... should be a snug fit (I used pliers to pop them in)
Slide screws onto switch
Place switch with screws thru holes and thread into nuts
... snug them but do not use brute force or you may break switch
Slide 2x m2 x 6mm screws thru slots on bracket
... snug them but do not use brute force or you may strip support threads
Thread screws into factory mount holes in support arm
Adjust switch to desired height

... can use longer m2 screws and thread thru support and put nuts on back if desired, mined worked just fine with threaded directly to support.
